Sunburn_1:
Patient Description 1:
A 25-year-old female patient presented with a chief complaint of inflamed skin, which appears as pink and feels hot to the touch. She reported a pain level of 6/10, accompanied by tenderness and itching in the affected areas. The patient has a history of prolonged sun exposure due to outdoor recreational activities and minimal use of sun protection. Physical examination revealed swelling and small, fluid-filled blisters on the sun-exposed areas. The patient denied any recent changes in medication or known photosensitivity. Given the contextual information of UV light exposure, sunburn ranks high in the differential diagnosis.
Sunburn_2:
Patient Description 2:
A 30-year-old male patient, with a Fitzpatrick skin type III, presented with a sunburn-related complaint. He described his skin as red and hot, with a pain level of 5/10, along with notable tenderness and itching. The patient reported a history of prolonged sun exposure during a beach vacation without adequate sun protection. Physical examination revealed inflamed skin and the presence of small, fluid-filled blisters. The patient denied any known photosensitivity or recent changes in medication. Given the clinical presentation and history of UV light exposure, sunburn is the most likely diagnosis.
Sunburn_3:
Patient Description 3:
A 40-year-old male patient, with a Fitzpatrick skin type VI, presented with skin discomfort following prolonged sun exposure. He described his skin as warm and tender, with a pain level of 7/10, and reported itching in the affected areas. The patient also complained of headache, fatigue, and nausea, suggesting a more severe sunburn. On examination, his skin appeared red, and he displayed small, fluid-filled blisters, along with swelling. The patient denied any known photosensitivity or recent medication changes. Given the severity of symptoms and the history of UV light exposure, sunburn is the likely diagnosis, with a presentation of moderate to severe sunburn.
